name: Powerhouse Nasir v1.0
description:
In which Nasir brings out the heavy artillery.

After a lot of conversation and some good back-and-forth, I've come to realize that Nasir might actually be one of the best big rig runners in the game. So I've built this deck around the old big-rig adage: "Efficient breakers, and the rest of your deck for money." Corps dread that beefy Shaper econ, and have to build up to make sure they can deal with it by the mid-game, by the time it's usually kicking in. But Nasir's ability, when played with proper Workshop or SMC use, turns economy, rig-building, and runs into the same thing - the main thing the corp usually does to slow you down (rezzing ice) is now the one thing that makes your early game so strong.

That need to make sure your econ is online ASAP is why this deck runs 3x Magnum Opus, and 3x Daily Casts. These will get you flush with cash to dump into a Personal Workshop during your runs, or to pop an SMC and get your big breakers out before your credit pool resets - and that's if the corp chooses to rez in the first place. If you have either your Workshop or an SMC on the table, and start a run with a lot of money, the corp player is forced into a position where they know you can deal with whatever ice they rez, and then have to decide whether it's even worth it to give you the money.

I'm running a Torch instead of a Gordian Blade, because I'm looking to make this deck hit as hard as it possibly can, and you should hardly be strapped for cash with this load-out. Inti is in as a safeguard to deal with the low-strength barriers in a pinch, and I almost always like to drop it before my Morning Star to get the corp comfortable with plopping down low-to mid strength barriers. I can also the case for a Snowball, or even dropping a Parasite to free up the influence for a Corroder, but I like it as it is now.

I've freed up space in the deck for 3x Maker's Eyes and 3x R&D Interface for deep, game-winning R&D digs.

Imp is in as a one-off to help you get rid of any assets should hit a SanSan you can't afford to trash or an NAPD you don't have the money to score. The deck also runs 2x Scavenges to give Imp extra staying power.

I've also one-offed a Crescentus to add another layer of pressure on the corp. It's the Nasir equivalent of Vamp, and acts as a great SMC-able way to kick the corp when they're down.

name: Scorching the Future
description: Made this as a backup deck to play when I'm not playing my main Jinteki RP deck (which is where the Hedge Funds live). Is HB Tag-and-Bag a thing?

name: YAA (Yet Another Andy) v.1
description:
Using this as a base to start tweaking. So far this has gone 1-3 in my local meta.

I feel like I have too many sentry breakers here...

name: Bigger stuff
description:
8 agendas in a 59 card deck for lowest agenda density odds of any deck.

3 x Oversight AI and 3 x Bioroid Efficiency Research to have a decent chance of getting one or two big bits of ICE up and running reasonably quickly.

The deck is designed to use oversight AIs and bioroid efficiency research to Rez large ice early, given that there are six of these cards in the deck. You then continuously rez large ice was attempting to bait the run into runs by installing in large remotes. When you want to score an agenda ash behind large ice should be successful in doing this, additionally using melange or GRNDL can net the corporation huge financial gains whilst costing the runner a huge amount to stop.

name: Nasir's Big Adventure
description: Consider ditching Same Old Thing and adding Dirty Laundry, Daily Casts, Inside Job

name: OverMeidan
description:
For anyone interested in how Rook helps Nasir on first-rez here's some data.

Only ICE Nasir cannot BREAK with Overmind on first-rez are (keep in mind some of these can be run through without a breaker, and this assumes about 3 power tokens):

Archer Bullfrog Chum Hunter Cell Portal Neural Katana Data Hound Data Mine Eli (can click through) Inazuma Janus 1.0 (unlikely without Deep Red) Komainu (unlikely without Deep Red) Hive (unlikely without Deep Red) Matrix Analyzer Rainbow RSVP Swordsman Tsurugi (unlikely without Deep Red) Viper Wotan (unlikely without Deep Red, alternate methods ok) Wraparound (without Fracter)

With a Rook on a server, this becomes:

Chum Hive Hunter Swordsman Wraparound (without Fracter) Janus 1.0 (unlikely without Deep Red) Archer (unlikely without Deep Red) Wotan (unlikely without Deep Red) Tsurugi (unlikely without Deep Red)

Think about that... If you have an Overmind AND a Rook out, only 9 unmodified ICE will bother you! Of those, only 5 ETR and of those, Wraparound, Tsurugi, and Hive are most likely to be seen.

On looking at the ICE data, Bishop is inferior to Rook in almost all cases. Knight is preferable as another way to deal with Wraparound. Hive is bad for OverMeidan, consider going somewhere else. Parasite seems best against Hive. Can remove one ACCT Siphon for a Planned Assault and put in a Parasite.

name: Trouble at the Noise
description:
I understand that this kind of thing is called a Mill. Lots of viruses, whose purposes is to be installed, sold, re-installed and sold again while throwing everything the corp has into the archives.

Question: I suppose/assume/guess that Noise decks have been designed without any need to run at all? Sounds terribly negative, but does anyone have examples of these?

name: Nasir MkV
description:
The Fall Guys are critical for post-0-rez/pocket money. Two fall guys = free NAPD contract for the game, for example. Or one for a Fetal. Or just to make a critical break. They do the heaviest lifting.

Don't be afraid to spend 3 clicks on Siphon > Remove Tag > Remove Tag if it means crippling the corp so they can't rez anything but 0c stuff.

name: Siphonless Gabe
description:
Trying to reduce the use of siphon, I feel it's effectiveness vs sustaining Gabe's economy is lessoning. Hoping a resource based economy can sustain his tempo.

Everything else is pretty standard, Gordian is now in for Lotus Field, but can be taken care of with Knight a bit better. Not 100% sure on including Gordian.

Mimic is just too good vs Jinteki at the moment.

Mid to late game legwork wins games, this is the point where Gabe usually loses and I feel it's a strong go to.

Indexing for R&D attack, planned assault is effectively the 2nd copy.

Because of the horizontal decks that are common; security testing, desperado, bank job and dirty laundry are incredibly powerful.

name: Soul Crusher
description: A pretty typical Jinteki RP deck, in my meta this style is nicknamed "Soul Crusher" simply because it kicks a player when they're down.

name: Checkmate
description: its basically a reina ice tax. it plays risky with no plascretes but i am trying it out. i have been able to combat all but a few corp's economy. tips ideas or suggestions?

name: Cold hard cash.
description: This deck has simple goals: Set up lots of ice, get cash often, score agendas somewhere in the mid-to-late-game range. No traps, just powerful ice and high-score agendas that interact with my ice.

name: Powerhouse Nasir v2.0
description:
After a lot of conversation and some good back-and-forth, I've come to realize that Nasir might actually be one of the best big rig runners in the game. So I've built this deck around the old big-rig adage: "Efficient breakers, and the rest of your deck for money." Corps dread that beefy Shaper econ, and have to build up to make sure they can deal with it by the mid-game, by the time it's usually kicking in. But Nasir's ability, when played with proper Workshop or SMC use, turns economy, rig-building, and runs into the same thing - the main thing the corp usually does to slow you down (rezzing ice) is now the one thing that makes your early game so strong.

This decks has econ in the form 2x Magnum Opus, and econ/draw from 3x Professional Contacts. These will get you flush with cash to dump into a Personal Workshop during your runs, or to pop an SMC and get your big breakers out before your credit pool resets - and that's if the corp chooses to rez in the first place. If you have either your Workshop or an SMC on the table, and start a run with a lot of money, the corp player is forced into a position where they know you can deal with whatever ice they rez, and then have to decide whether it's even worth it to give you the money.

New in v2.0, I've retooled the breaker suite and have dropped Torch for a Gordian Blade. I've also freed up space for 3x Atmans by dropping a Clone Chip, an RDI and a Test Run. I found myself overdrawing into these cards more often than not, which might not seem like a bad thing, but recurring with Clone Chip isn't as important as I thought it would be. Plus you only need two RDI's online before each run becomes a Maker's Eye. And running Atman with a rich Nasir should get you into plenty of servers.

Indexing is also down to only one copy. I find myself always wanting to hold them for the perfect situations, and those don't come up terribly often once you get out of the early game. The last thing I need is an extra card clogging up my hand, or my deck.

Imp stays in as a one-off to help you get rid of any assets should hit a SanSan you can't afford to trash or an NAPD you don't have the money to score (then money up, and snatch it from archives). The deck also runs 3x Scavenges to give Imp extra staying power. You can also use it to retool strength on Atman or reposition your Femme token.

I've also one-offed a Crescentus to add another layer of pressure on the corp. It's the Nasir equivalent of Vamp, only more powerful, and acts as a great SMC-able way to kick the corp when they're down.
